p: There are several countries that have developed elimination plans [3,4]. One of the most successful countries is Egypt, where many are already cured, and mass testing programmes are identifying the millions of individuals who are unaware of their infection [7]. Not only adults are included in these programmes: Egypt is also including children and adolescents. By testing and treating the young population, parents are also engaged in testing. In addition, adolescents tend to strengthen the community by raising awareness and advocacy. During the testing programme, stigma in schools or when parents where asked for consent for testing of their child has been identified. By working together with organisations such as the national mother and child organisation, knowledge is gained regarding the protection of children from discrimination and stigma. This approach can be an example for other countries, since worldwide over 11 million children (under the age of 15) have HCV infection [8].
